'''''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'''''{{efn|name=stylized|Stylized onscreen as '''''Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood''''' and in promotional materials as '''''Once Upon a Time in... Hollywood'''''}} is a 2019 <!-- DO NOT ADD OR CHANGE MORE GENRES. The film is a comedy drama film. Not crime, action or more so. Period Drama doesn't count from the reason it's an alternative history --> [[comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Quentin Tarantino]]. Produced by [[Columbia Pictures]], [[Bona Film Group]], [[Heyday Films]], and Visiona Romantica and distributed by [[Sony Pictures Releasing]], it is a co-production between the United States, United Kingdom, and China. It features a large [[ensemble cast]] led by [[Leonardo DiCaprio]], [[Brad Pitt]], and [[Margot Robbie]]. Set in 1969 Los Angeles, the film follows an actor and his stunt double as they navigate the changing film industry, and features "multiple storylines in a modern fairy tale tribute to the final moments of [[Classical Hollywood cinema|Hollywood's golden age]]."<ref name="synopis">{{cite news |title=Once Upon a Time In... Hollywood Movie Synopsis {{!}} Official Website {{!}} Sony Pictures |url=https://www.onceuponatimeinhollywood.movie/synopsis/ |accessdate=March 22, 2019 |work=Once Upon a Time In... Hollywood |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190322054919/https://www.onceuponatimeinhollywood.movie/synopsis/ |archive-date=March 22, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Olson |first1=Matthew |url=http://digg.com/2019/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-reviews-is-it-good-tarantino-dicaprio-robbie-pitt |title=Does Quentin Tarantino's 'Once Upon A Time In Hollywood' Live Up To The Hype? Here's What Critics Say |publisher=Digg.com |accessdate=July 25, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190724215302/http://digg.com/2019/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-reviews-is-it-good-tarantino-dicaprio-robbie-pitt |archive-date=July 24, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-harvey-weinstein-sony-manson-movie |title=Quentin Tarantino Is Ditching Weinstein for Sony |last=Sperling |first=Nicole |date=November 17, 2017 |website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |accessdate=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180225160449/https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-harvey-weinstein-sony-manson-movie|archive-date=February 25, 2018}}</ref>
Announced in July 2017, it is the first Tarantino film not to involve [[Bob Weinstein|Bob]] and [[Harvey Weinstein]], as Tarantino ended his partnership with the brothers following the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse cases|sexual abuse allegations against the latter]]. After a bidding war, the film was distributed by [[Sony Pictures]], which met Tarantino's demands including [[final cut privilege]]. Pitt, DiCaprio, Robbie, [[Zoë Bell]], [[Kurt Russell]], and others joined the cast between January and June 2018. [[Principal photography]] lasted from June through November around Los Angeles. This was the final film to feature [[Luke Perry]], who died on March 4, 2019.
''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'' premiered at the [[2019 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]] on May 21, 2019, and was theatrically released in the United States on July 26, 2019 and in the United Kingdom on August 14. The film has grossed $374 million worldwide and received praise from critics for Tarantino's screenplay and direction, acting, cinematography, costume design, production values, and soundtrack. Among its [[List of accolades received by Once Upon a Time in Hollywood|various accolades]], the film was chosen by the [[American Film Institute]] and the [[National Board of Review]] as one of the top ten films of the year. It received 10 nominations at the [[92nd Academy Awards]], including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], and won [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] (Pitt) and [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Production Design]]. It also won [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]] at the [[77th Golden Globe Awards]].
A television series of ''Bounty Law'' depicted in the film is being developed by Tarantino, who has written five episodes of the series.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.esquireme.com/content/42823-quentin-tarantino-is-making-a-real-life-bounty-law-tv-show|title=Quentin Tarantino is making a real-life 'Bounty Law' TV show|website=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire Middle East]]|publisher=[[Hearst Communications]]|language=en|date=January 13, 2020|access-date=February 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200213213933/https://www.esquireme.com/content/42823-quentin-tarantino-is-making-a-real-life-bounty-law-tv-show|archive-date=February 13, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Nash">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gq.com.au/entertainment/film-tv/quentin-tarantino-plans-to-turn-fictional-western-bounty-law-into-a-real-series/news-story/a2e81c7d1d29df7e5782eb19e1f2d87b|title=Quentin Tarantino Plans To Turn Fictional Western Bounty Law Into A Real Series|last=Nash|first=Brad|date=2020-01-21|website=GQ|language=en|access-date=2020-02-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200213213937/https://www.gq.com.au/entertainment/film-tv/quentin-tarantino-plans-to-turn-fictional-western-bounty-law-into-a-real-series/news-story/a2e81c7d1d29df7e5782eb19e1f2d87b|archive-date=February 13, 2020|url-status=live}}</ref>
== Plot == <!-- Per WP:FILMPLOT, plot summaries for feature films should be between 400 to 700 words only. --> In February 1969, veteran [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]] actor Rick Dalton, star of 1950s [[Western (genre)|Western]] television series ''Bounty Law'', fears his career is fading. Casting agent Marvin Schwarz recommends he make [[Spaghetti Western]]s in Italy, which Dalton feels are beneath him. Dalton's best friend and [[stunt double]], Cliff Booth—a war [[veteran]] skilled in hand-to-hand combat<ref>{{citation |title=Quentin Tarantino defends Bruce Lee scene in 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' |url=https://us.blastingnews.com/showbiz-tv/2019/08/quentin-tarantino-defends-bruce-lee-scene-in-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-002965405.html |accessdate=January 6, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191104220815/https://us.blastingnews.com/showbiz-tv/2019/08/quentin-tarantino-defends-bruce-lee-scene-in-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-002965405.html |archive-date=November 4, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> who lives in a tiny trailer with his [[pit bull]], Brandy—drives Dalton around Los Angeles because Dalton's driver's license has been suspended due to [[DUI]]. Booth struggles to find stunt work in Hollywood because of rumors he murdered his wife. Actress [[Sharon Tate]] and her husband, director [[Roman Polanski]], have moved [[10050 Cielo Drive|next door to Dalton]], who dreams of befriending them to revive his declining acting career. That night, Tate and Polanski attend a celebrity-filled party at the [[Playboy Mansion]].
The next day, while repairing Dalton's TV antenna, Booth reminisces about a [[sparring]] contest he had with [[Bruce Lee]] on the set of ''[[The Green Hornet (TV series)|The Green Hornet]]'' which resulted in Booth being fired. Meanwhile, [[Charles Manson]] stops by the Polanski residence looking for [[Record producer|producer]] [[Terry Melcher]], who used to live there, but is turned away by [[Jay Sebring]]. Tate goes for errands and stops at a movie theater to watch herself in the film ''[[The Wrecking Crew (1968 film)|The Wrecking Crew]]''.
Dalton is cast to play the villain in the pilot of ''[[Lancer (TV series)|Lancer]]'', and strikes up a conversation with his eight-year-old co-star, Trudi Fraser. During filming, Dalton struggles to remember his lines and later suffers a breakdown in his trailer as a result. He subsequently delivers a strong performance that impresses Fraser and the director, [[Sam Wanamaker]], bolstering his confidence.
While driving Dalton's car, Booth picks up a female hitchhiker named Pussycat, whom he takes to [[Spahn Ranch]], where Booth once worked on the set of ''Bounty Law.'' He takes notice of the many [[hippie]]s living there (the [[Manson Family]]). Suspecting they may be taking advantage of the ranch's owner, [[George Spahn]], Booth insists on checking on him despite [[Lynette Fromme|"Squeaky" Fromme]]'s objections. Booth finally speaks with Spahn, who dismisses his concerns. Upon leaving, Booth discovers that [[Steve "Clem" Grogan]] has slashed a tire on Dalton's car; Booth beats him and forces him to change the tire. [[Tex Watson]] is summoned to deal with the situation but he arrives as Booth is driving away.
After watching Dalton's guest performance on an episode of ''[[The F.B.I. (TV series)|The F.B.I.]]'', Schwarz books him as the lead in [[Sergio Corbucci]]'s next Spaghetti Western, ''Nebraska Jim''. Dalton takes Booth with him for a six-month stint in Italy, during which time he films two additional Westerns and a [[Eurospy film|Eurospy]] comedy, and marries Italian starlet Francesca Capucci. With a new wife, Dalton informs Booth he can no longer afford his services.
On the evening of August 8, 1969, their first day back in Los Angeles, Dalton and Booth go out for drinks to commemorate their time working together and then return to Dalton's house. Tate and Sebring go out for dinner with friends and then return to Tate's house. Booth smokes an [[Lysergic acid diethylamide|acid]]-laced cigarette purchased earlier from a hippy girl and takes Brandy for a walk while Dalton prepares drinks. Manson Family members Tex, [[Susan Atkins|Sadie]], [[Linda Kasabian|Flowerchild]], and [[Patricia Krenwinkel|Katie]] arrive outside in preparation to [[Tate–LaBianca murders|murder everyone in Tate's house]]. Dalton hears their loud car and orders them off his street. Recognizing Dalton, the Manson Family members [[Alternate history|change their plans]] and decide to kill him instead, after Sadie reasons that Hollywood has "taught them to murder". Flowerchild deserts the group, speeding off with their car. They break into Dalton's house and confront Capucci and Booth, who recognizes them from his visit to Spahn Ranch. Booth orders Brandy to attack, and together they kill Katie and Tex and injure Sadie, though Booth is stabbed and knocked unconscious in the altercation. Sadie stumbles outside, alarming Dalton, who is in his pool listening to music on headphones, oblivious to the melee inside. Dalton retrieves a flamethrower previously used in a movie and incinerates Sadie. After Booth is taken to the hospital to treat his injuries, Sebring engages Dalton in conversation outside and Dalton receives an invitation for a drink with Tate and her friends at her house, which he accepts.

== Production == === Writing and development === [[File:Quentin Tarantino by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Director [[Quentin Tarantino]] developed the idea over the course of several years, looking to tell a "[[fairy tale]]" set in 1960s [[Hollywood]].]] The work that would become the screenplay for ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'' was developed slowly over several years by Tarantino. While he knew he wanted the work to be titled ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'', evoking the idea of a fairy tale set in 1960s Hollywood, he publicly referred to the project as ''Magnum Opus''.<ref name="esquire may2019">{{cite magazine | url = https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/a27458589/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-leonardo-dicaprio-brad-pitt-quentin-tarantino-interview/ | title = Quentin Tarantino, Brad Pitt, and Leonardo DiCaprio Take You Inside 'Once Upon a Time...In Hollywood' | first = Michael | last = Hainey | date = May 21, 2019 | accessdate = January 19, 2020 | magazine = [[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20191004074617/https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/movies/a27458589/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-leonardo-dicaprio-brad-pitt-quentin-tarantino-interview/ | archive-date = October 4, 2019 | url-status = live }}</ref> The life of the work for the first five years was as a novel,<ref name="esquire may2019"/> which Tarantino considered to be an exploratory approach to the story he wanted to tell, not yet having decided if it would be a screenplay. Tarantino tried other writing approaches: the early scene between DiCaprio's Dalton and Pacino's Marvin Schwarz was originally written as a one-act play as part of this exploratory work.<ref name="gamespot inspiration"/>
Tarantino discovered the centerpiece for the work in 2009 while filming a movie with an actor that had the same stunt double for 20 years. Even though there was nothing but a small bit for the stuntman to do, Tarantino was asked to use him, and he agreed. The relationship fascinated Tarantino and inspired him to make a film about Hollywood.<ref name=recut/> Tarantino said that while the stuntman may have been a perfect double for the actor years earlier, at the time he had come to meet them, "this was maybe the last or second-to-last thing they'd be doing together".<ref name="gamespot inspiration">{{cite web | url = https://www.gamespot.com/articles/quentin-tarantino-reveals-inspiration-behind-once-/1100-6472880/ | title = Quentin Tarantino Reveals Inspiration Behind Once Upon A Time In Hollywood | first = James | last = O'Conner | date = January 19, 2020 | accessdate = January 19, 2020 | work = [[GameSpot]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200120073855/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/quentin-tarantino-reveals-inspiration-behind-once-/1100-6472880/ | archive-date = January 20, 2020 | url-status = live }}</ref>
Tarantino first created Cliff Booth, giving him a massive backstory. Then, the actor Booth was the stunt double for Rick Dalton. Tarantino decided to have them be [[Sharon Tate]]'s next-door neighbors in 1969. The first plot point he developed was the ending, then moved backwards from there, this being the first time Tarantino had worked this way. He thought of doing an [[Elmore Leonard]]-type story, but realized he was confident enough in his characters to let them drive the film and let it be a day in the life of Booth, Dalton, and Tate. He would use sequences from Dalton's films for the action, inspired by [[Richard Rush (director)|Richard Rush]]'s ''[[The Stunt Man]]'', which used the scenes from the [[WWI]] movie they were making within the film as the action.<ref>{{cite podcast |last=Lattanzio |first=Ryan |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/quentin-tarantino-paul-thomas-anderson-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-podcast-1202168301 |title=Listen to Quentin Tarantino and Paul Thomas Anderson Talk 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' |website=[[IndieWire]] |access-date=September 5, 2019 |date=August 24, 2019 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20190829013436/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/quentin-tarantino-paul-thomas-anderson-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-podcast-1202168301/ |archivedate=August 29, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> Further, to get his mind into the Dalton character, Tarantino wrote out five hypothetical episodes of the fictional television show ''Bounty Law'', in which Dalton had starred, having become fascinated with the amount of story crammed into half-hour episodes of 1950s western shows. Tarantino has expressed interest in turning these five scripts, as well as ideas for three more, into an actual ''Bounty Law'' television series in the future.<ref name=Tarantino-Deadline-Interview/>
=== Pre-production === On July 11, 2017, it was announced that [[Quentin Tarantino]]'s next film would be about the [[Manson Family]] murders. [[Harvey Weinstein|Harvey]] and [[Bob Weinstein]] would be involved, but it was not known whether [[The Weinstein Company]] would distribute the film, as Tarantino sought to cast before sending out a package to studios. Tarantino approached [[Brad Pitt]] and [[Jennifer Lawrence]] to star in the film. It was reported that [[Margot Robbie]] was being considered for [[Sharon Tate]].<ref name="FirsReportedTHR"/> [[Samuel L. Jackson]] was in talks for a major role, and Pitt was in talks for the detective investigating the murders.<ref name="FirsReportedDeadline"/>
After the [[Harvey Weinstein sexual abuse allegations]], Tarantino cut ties with Weinstein and sought a new distributor, after having worked with Weinstein for his entire career. At this point, [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] was revealed to be among a short list of actors Tarantino was considering for the film.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fleming Jr |first1=Mike |title=Quentin Tarantino Seeking New Movie Home: Studios Reading #9 This Week |url=https://deadline.com/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-new-home-studios-reading-number-9-harvey-weinstein-1202199806/ |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=November 8, 2017 |date=November 1, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108094853/http://deadline.com/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-new-home-studios-reading-number-9-harvey-weinstein-1202199806/|archive-date=November 8, 2017}}</ref> A short time later, reports circulated that studios were bidding for the film set in Los Angeles in the late 1960s, that [[Tom Cruise]] was in talks for one of the leads, and that [[David Heyman]] had joined as a producer, along with Tarantino and [[Shannon McIntosh (filmmaker)|Shannon McIntosh]].<ref name="HeymanProducer"/>
On November 11, 2017, [[Sony Pictures]] announced they would distribute the film, beating [[Warner Bros.]], [[Universal Pictures]], [[Paramount Pictures]], [[Annapurna Pictures]] and [[Lionsgate]].<ref name="SonyWins">{{cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-sony-pictures-wins-auction-charles-manson-margot-robbie-tom-cruise-brad-pitt-leonardo-dicaprio-1202210597/ |title=Sony Pictures Confirms Quentin Tarantino Deal; Margot Robbie, Tom Cruise, Brad Pitt, Leonardo DiCaprio Circling |last=Fleming Jr. |first=Mike |date=November 17, 2017 |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618152249/https://deadline.com/2017/11/quentin-tarantino-sony-pictures-wins-auction-charles-manson-margot-robbie-tom-cruise-brad-pitt-leonardo-dicaprio-1202210597/|archive-date=June 18, 2018}}</ref> Tarantino's demands included a $95 million budget, [[final cut privilege]], "extraordinary creative controls", 25% of [[first-dollar gross]],<ref name="auto">{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-sony-nabbed-quentin-tarantinos-manson-movie-1059742 |title=How Sony Nabbed Quentin Tarantino's Manson Movie |last=Kit |first=Borys |date=November 18, 2017 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616205706/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-sony-nabbed-quentin-tarantinos-manson-movie-1059742|archive-date=June 16, 2018}}</ref> and the stipulation that the rights revert to him after 10 to 20 years.<ref name="auto"/>

=== Filming and design === {{multiple image|total_width=270|image1=Burt_Reynolds_1970.JPG |image2=Bruce Dern by Gage Skidmore.jpg|footer=With the death of [[Burt Reynolds]] (left), the role of [[George Spahn]] was recast with [[Bruce Dern]]}} [[Principal photography]] began on June 18, 2018, in Los Angeles, California, and [[Wrap (filmmaking)|wrapped]] on November 1, 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://omegaunderground.com/2018/05/24/tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-begins-filming-on-june-18th-in-la/ |title=Tarantino's 'Once Upon A Time in Hollywood' Begins Filming on June 18th in LA |last=Marc |first=Christopher |date=May 24, 2018 |website=Omega Underground |accessdate=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618125719/https://omegaunderground.com/2018/05/24/tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-begins-filming-on-june-18th-in-la/|archive-date=June 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.backstage.com/resources/detail/productionlisting/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-86666/ |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood |website=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]] |accessdate=November 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190322012929/https://www.backstage.com/resources/detail/productionlisting/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-86666/|archive-date=March 22, 2019}}</ref> Reynolds died in September 2018 before filming any of his scenes; [[Bruce Dern]] was cast as [[George Spahn]] in his place.<ref name="Dern"/>
Tarantino's directive was to turn Los Angeles of 2018 into Los Angeles of 1969 without [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]].<ref name="afar"/> For this, Tarantino tapped into previous collaborators for production: editor [[Fred Raskin]], cinematographer [[Robert Richardson (cinematographer)|Robert Richardson]], sound editor [[Wylie Stateman]] and makeup artist Heba Thorisdottir. He also brought first-time collaborators production designer Barbara Ling based on her work in recreating historical settings in ''[[The Doors (film)|The Doors]]'', and costume designer [[Arianne Phillips]], who had a strong client list to her name including [[Tom Ford]], [[James Mangold]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].<ref name="variety making 60s">{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2020/artisans/production/quentin-tarantino-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-2-1203484354/ | title = Quentin Tarantino on Re-Creating 1960s L.A. for 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' | first = Jazz | last = Tangcay | date = January 29, 2020 | accessdate = January 29, 2020 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200129201909/https://variety.com/2020/artisans/production/quentin-tarantino-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-2-1203484354/ | archive-date = January 29, 2020 | url-status = live }}</ref>
To film at the Pussycat Theater, production designer Barbara Ling and her team covered the building's [[LED]] signage and reattached the theater's iconic logo, rebuilding the letters and neon. Ling said the lettering on every marquee in the film is historically accurate. To restore Larry Edmund's Bookshop, she reproduced the original storefront sign and tracked down period-appropriate merchandise, even recreating book covers. For the Bruin and Fox Village theaters Ling's team restored the theaters, their marquees, and the storefronts around them. Stan's Donuts, across the street from the Bruin, got a complete makeover.<ref name="afar">{{cite news |last=Wakim |first=Marielle |url=https://www.afar.com/magazine/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-filming-locations-you-can-visit-in-los-angeles |title='Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood' Filming Locations You Can Visit in Los Angeles |website=[[Afar (magazine)|Afar]] |access-date=September 2, 2019 |date=July 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190903051130/https://www.afar.com/magazine/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-filming-locations-you-can-visit-in-los-angeles |archive-date=September 3, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> [[File:Playboy Mansion North Side 2007.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Filming at the [[Playboy Mansion]] saw a lengthy negotiation period to secure permission.]] The [[Playboy Mansion]] scene was shot at the actual mansion.<ref name=recreating-hollywood/><ref>{{cite web |last=Combemale |first=Leslie |url=https://www.mpaa.org/2019/08/artist-steve-chorney-on-crafting-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywoods-poster-more/ |title=Artist Steve Chorney on Crafting ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood''{{'}}s Poster & More |website=[[Motion Picture Association of America]]| access-date=September 8, 2019 |date=August 12, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Minow |first=Nell |url=https://www.mpaa.org/2019/08/meet-the-caricaturist-who-created-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywoods-classic-mad-magazine-cover/ |title=Meet the Caricaturist who Created 'Once Upon a Time in... Hollywood's' Classic MAD Magazine Cover |website=[[Motion Picture Association of America]]| access-date=September 8, 2019 |date=August 1, 2019}}</ref> Tarantino was adamant about filming at that location, but it took a long time to obtain permission since by the time of pre-production the mansion had been sold to a private owner following [[Hugh Hefner]]'s death. Tarantino and Ling met with the new owner to discuss the parts of the property which they wanted to use, but he was reluctant since the property was in the middle of a renovation. After long negotiations he agreed, and Ling was able to dress the vacant mansion, front courtyard, and backyard for the party scene, evoking as much of the 1960s appearance of the mansion as possible.<ref name=recreating-Hollywood/>
The scenes involving the Tate–Polanski house were not filmed at Cielo Drive, the winding street where the 3,200 square-foot house once stood. The original house was razed in 1994 and replaced with a mansion nearly six-times the size. Scenes involving the Tate-Polanski house were filmed at three different locations around Los Angeles: one for the interior scenes, one for the scenes showing the exterior of the old house, and a Universal City location for the many scenes depicting the iconic cul-de-sac driveway.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/recreate-sharon-tate-s-benedict-canyon-house-quentin-tarantino-turned-a-la-tour-guide-1227436 |title=Archived copy |access-date=April 10, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200203050926/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/recreate-sharon-tate-s-benedict-canyon-house-quentin-tarantino-turned-a-la-tour-guide-1227436 |archive-date=February 3, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref>
For ''Bounty Law'', Ling went for a dusty, dirty, early ''[[Deadwood (TV series)|Deadwood]]'' look. Movie poster artist [[Steven Chorney]] created the poster for the film, as a reference to ''[[The Mod Squad]]''. He also created the posters for ''Nebraska Jim'', ''Operation Dyn-O-Mite'', ''Uccidimi Subito Ringo Disse il Gringo'', ''Hell-Fire Texas'', and ''Comanche Uprising'', which was reprinted for Dalton's home parking spot. [[Mad (magazine)|''Mad'']] magazine caricaturist [[Tom Richmond (illustrator)|Tom Richmond]] created the covers of ''Mad'' and ''[[TV Guide]]'' featuring Dalton's Jake Cahill. Spahn Ranch was recreated in detail over about a three-month period.
Tarantino told cinematographer [[Robert Richardson (cinematographer)|Robert Richardson]], "I want it to feel retro but I want it to be contemporary." Richardson shot in [[Kodak]] [[35 mm movie film|35mm]] with [[Panavision]] cameras and lenses, in order to weave time periods. For ''Bounty Law'' they shot in black and white, and brief sequences in [[Super 8 film|Super 8]] and [[16mm]] [[Ektachrome]]. In the film, ''[[Lancer (TV series)|Lancer]]'' was shot on a retrofitted Western Street backlot at [[Universal Pictures|Universal Studios]], designed by Ling. Richardson crossed ''Lancer'' with ''[[Alias Smith and Jones]]'' for the retro-future look Tarantino wanted. The way they filmed ''Lancer'' was not possible in 1969, but Tarantino wanted his personal touch on it. Richardson said that filming the movie touched him personally, "The film speaks to all of us... We are all fragile beings with a limited time to achieve whatever it is we desire... that at any moment that place will shift... So take stock in life and have the courage to believe in yourself."<ref name=recreating-hollywood>{{cite web |last=Han |first=Karen |url=https://www.polygon.com/2019/7/28/8932339/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-playboy-mansion |title=What it took to get the Playboy Mansion for Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood |website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |access-date=September 3, 2019 |date=July 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190906142247/https://www.polygon.com/2019/7/28/8932339/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-playboy-mansion |archive-date=September 6, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Desowitz |first=Bill |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-cinematographer-robert-richardson-quentin-tarantino-1969-1202159937/ |title="Once Upon a Time in Hollywood": How Cinematographer Robert Richardson captured 1969 in 2019 |website=[[IndieWire]] |access-date=September 3, 2019 |date=July 22, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190723131120/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-cinematographer-robert-richardson-quentin-tarantino-1969-1202159937/ |archive-date=July 23, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
The exterior of the Van Nuys drive-in scene was filmed at the Paramount Theater since the Van Nuys Theater no longer exists. As the camera rises up over the theater, the shot transitions to a miniature set with toy cars.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2477166/cool-tricks-quentin-tarantino-used-to-recreate-1969-la-for-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood| title=Cool Tricks Quentin Tarantino Used to Recreate 1969 L.A. For Once Upon a Time in Hollywood| date=July 26, 2019| access-date=November 9, 2019|publisher=CinemaBlend| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191109202340/https://www.cinemablend.com/news/2477166/cool-tricks-quentin-tarantino-used-to-recreate-1969-la-for-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood| archive-date=November 9, 2019| url-status=live}}</ref> For some of the driving scenes, Los Angeles freeways were shut down for hours in order to fill them with vintage cars.<ref name=cinema-blend/>

== Reception == === Box office === ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'' grossed $142.5 million in the United States and Canada, and $231.8 million in other territories, for a worldwide total of $374.3 million.<ref name="BOM"/> By some estimates, the film needed to gross around $250 million worldwide in order to [[break-even]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Lee |first=Chris |url=https://www.vulture.com/2019/08/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-box-office-bet-pays-off.html |title=The Bet on ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'' Is Paying Off |website=[[New York (magazine)#Digital expansion and blogs|Vulture]] |access-date=September 6, 2019 |date=August 5, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190805145753/https://www.vulture.com/2019/08/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-box-office-bet-pays-off.html |archive-date=August 5, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> with others estimating it would need to make $400 million in order to turn a profit.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/once-a-time-hollywood-debut-doesnt-guarantee-a-happy-ending-1227512 |title=Box Office: Why 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood's' $40M Debut Doesn't Guarantee a Fairy Tale Ending |date=July 29, 2019 |first=Pamela|last= McClintock |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=August 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190809094907/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/once-a-time-hollywood-debut-doesnt-guarantee-a-happy-ending-1227512 |archive-date=August 9, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
In the United States and Canada, the film was projected to gross $30–40 million from 3,659 theaters in its opening weekend, with some projections having it as high as $50 million or as low as $25 million.<ref name=EarlyProjections>{{Cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2019/07/quentin-tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-eyes-30m-opening-1202641601/ |title=Quentin Tarantino's 'Once Upon A Time In Hollywood' Eyes $30M Opening |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=July 3, 2019 |access-date=July 3, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190703161646/https://deadline.com/2019/07/quentin-tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-eyes-30m-opening-1202641601/ |archive-date=July 3, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-box-office/ |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood': Will Sony's Bet on Quentin Tarantino Pay Off? |last=Fuster |first=Jeremy |website=[[TheWrap]] |date=July 23, 2019 |access-date=July 24, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190724035722/https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-box-office/ |archive-date=July 24, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> The week of its release, [[Fandango (company)|Fandango]] reported the film was the highest pre-seller of any Tarantino film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-biggest-fandango-preseller-1202652829/ |title='Once Upon A Time In Hollywood' Is Quentin Tarantino's Biggest Preseller On Fandango |last=D'Alessandro |first=Anthony |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=July 24, 2019 |access-date=July 24, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190724202322/https://deadline.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-biggest-fandango-preseller-1202652829/ |archive-date=July 24, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> The film made $16.9 million on its first day, including $5.8 million from Thursday night previews (the highest total of Tarantino's career). It went on to debut to $41.1 million, finishing second behind holdover ''[[The Lion King (2019 film)|The Lion King]]'' and marking Tarantino's largest opening. [[Comscore]] reported that 47% of audience members went to see the film because of who the director was (compared to the typical 7%) and 37% went because of the cast (compared to normally 18%).<ref name=opening>{{Cite web |url=https://deadline.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-box-office-lion-king-weekend-1202654606/ |title=Hooray For 'Hollywood': Quentin Tarantino Sees His Biggest B.O. === Critical response === [[File:Brad Pitt 2019 by Glenn Francis.jpg|thumb|left|160px|In addition to receiving critical praise for his performance, Pitt's character Cliff Booth saw praise on a moral and theological level.]] On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 85% based on 530 reviews, with an [[Weighted arithmetic mean|average rating]] of 7.82/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "Thrillingly unrestrained yet solidly crafted, ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'' tempers Tarantino's provocative impulses with the clarity of a mature filmmaker's vision."<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/once_upon_a_time_in_hollywood |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood (2019) |website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=May 4, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330050307/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/once_upon_a_time_in_hollywood |archive-date=March 30, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> [[Metacritic]] assigned the film a [[weighted average]] score of 83 out of 100, based on 61 critics, indicating "universal acclaim."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/movie/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=September 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190722083158/https://www.metacritic.com/movie/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood |archive-date=July 22, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave it an average grade of "B" on an A+ to F scale, while those at [[PostTrak]] gave it an average of 4 out of 5 stars and a 58% "definite recommend."<ref name="opening"/>

== Pop culture references == The title is a reference to director [[Sergio Leone]]'s second western/American trilogy, ''[[Once Upon a Time in the West]]'', ''Once Upon a Time… the Revolution'' (which producers insisted on retitling ''[[Duck, You Sucker!]]'' ), and ''[[Once Upon a Time in America]]''.<ref name=easter-eggs/>
Archive footage from many films is included in ''Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'', including ''[[C.C. and Company]]'', ''[[Lady in Cement]]'', ''[[Three in the Attic]]'', and ''[[The Wrecking Crew (1968 film)|The Wrecking Crew]]'', in which [[Sharon Tate]] appears as Freya Carlson. Three scenes were digitally altered, replacing the original actors with Rick Dalton. One from an episode of ''[[The F.B.I. (TV series)|The F.B.I.]]'', entitled "All the Streets Are Silent," in which Dalton appears as a character originally portrayed by [[Burt Reynolds]]. Another from ''[[Death on the Run]]'', with Dalton's face imposed over [[Ty Hardin]]'s. The third is from ''[[The Great Escape (film)|The Great Escape]]'', with Dalton appearing as Virgil Hilts, the role made famous by [[Steve McQueen]].<ref name=easter-eggs>{{cite news |url=https://screenrant.com/once-upon-time-hollywood-movie-easter-eggs-cameos/ |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood: Every Easter Egg, Tarantino Reference & Cameo |website=[[Screen Rant]] |last=Hunt |first=James |access-date=August 16, 2019 |date=August 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190816180441/https://screenrant.com/once-upon-time-hollywood-movie-easter-eggs-cameos/ |archive-date=August 16, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=FakeMovies>{{cite news |url=https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-what-real-movies-inspired-rick-daltons-fake-films/ |title='Once Upon a Time in Hollywood': What Real Movies Inspired Rick Dalton's Fake Films? |work=[[TheWrap]] |last=Welk |first=Brian |access-date=August 13, 2019 |date=July 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190814094933/https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-what-real-movies-inspired-rick-daltons-fake-films/ |archive-date=August 14, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Archive footage"/> For ''The 14 Fists of McCluskey'', a WWII film within the film starring Dalton, footage and music from ''[[Hell River]]'' is used.<ref>{{cite web |last=Tate |first=James M. |url=http://www.cultfilmfreaks.com/2019/08/hell-river.html |title=How 'Hell River' Connects 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' |website=cult film freak |access-date=September 4, 2019 |date=August 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190905020522/http://www.cultfilmfreaks.com/2019/08/hell-river.html |archive-date=September 5, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> Additionally, Martin Abrahams, [[Brioni Farrell]], Victor Freitag, [[Nancy Kwan]], [[Dean Martin]], [[Hannes Messemer]], [[Gordon Mitchell]], [[Rod Taylor]], [[Burt Ward]], and [[Adam West]] appear via archive footage and sound.
The 1959 [[Ford Galaxie]] driven by the Manson Family is a detailed replica of the car used in the Tate–LaBianca murders. Car coordinator Steven Butcher found the actual car, but after a meeting with Tarantino, they decided using it would be "too creepy."<ref name=vintage-cars>{{cite news |url=https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-cars-reservoir-dogs/ |title=Quentin Tarantino used an 'Absurd Amount of Vintage Cars in 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'{{'}} |website=[[TheWrap]] |last=Welk |first=Brian |access-date=August 14, 2019 |date=July 31, 2019 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190814161623/https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-cars-reservoir-dogs/ |archive-date=August 14, 2019}}</ref>
[[Mark Lindsay]], lead singer of [[Paul Revere & the Raiders]], whose music is featured in the film, once lived at [[10050 Cielo Drive]], the address of the Tate murders. On the poster of Dalton's film ''Red Blood Red Skin'', inspired by ''[[Land Raiders (film)|Land Raiders]]'', he appears with [[Telly Savalas]]. The posters for the two films are the same, except with Dalton replacing [[George Maharis]]. The movie Voytek Frykowski is watching is ''[[Teenage Monster]]'', presented by horror host [[Larry Vincent|Seymour]].<ref name=FakeMovies/><ref name=annotated>{{cite news |url=https://film.avclub.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-annotated-1836793225 |title=Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood... annotated |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |access-date=September 1, 2019 |date=August 2, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190804014912/https://film.avclub.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-annotated-1836793225 |archive-date=August 4, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
=== Connections to other Tarantino films === Cliff Booth is a reference to Brad Pitt's character in ''Inglourious Basterds'', Aldo Raine, who takes the cover of a stuntman.<ref name=easter-eggs/> Dalton stars in a Spaghetti Western directed by Antonio Margheriti which is a reference to an alias used by the Basterds.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-inglourious-basterds-easter-egg-explained-1202160949/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=February 12, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190806120936/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-inglourious-basterds-easter-egg-explained-1202160949/ |archive-date=August 6, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> When Dalton and Booth get back from Italy they walk by the blue mosaic wall in [[LAX]], the same wall that the title character in Tarantino's ''[[Jackie Brown]]'' ([[Pam Grier]]) moves past in the opening credits of that film.<ref name=39-details>{{cite news |last=Snyder |first=Chris |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/quentin-tarantino-once-upon-time-hollywood-details-you-missed-2019-7 |title=39 details you may have missed in Tarantino's "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" |website=Business Insider |access-date=September 15, 2019 |date=August 2, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190803025838/https://www.businessinsider.com/quentin-tarantino-once-upon-time-hollywood-details-you-missed-2019-7 |archive-date=August 3, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
In the film, Lee engages in a fight with Cliff Booth on the set of ''The Green Hornet''.<ref name=39-details/><ref name=controversial-scene/> The ''Green Hornet'' [[Flight of the Bumblebee|theme song]] is featured in Tarantino's ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 1]]''.<ref name=39-details/> The masks worn by the Crazy 88 gang in that film are the same as Lee's mask as Kato in ''The Green Hornet''.<ref>{{cite web |last=Siller |first=Alexandra |title=O-Ren Ishii: Samurai of The Underworld |url=https://medium.com/@acs58312/in-the-eyes-of-kill-bill-s-o-ren-ishii-311c7f5bffe8 |website=Medium |date=April 3, 2016 |access-date=September 28, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170113182430/https://medium.com/@acs58312/in-the-eyes-of-kill-bill-s-o-ren-ishii-311c7f5bffe8 |archive-date=January 13, 2017 |url-status=live}}</ref> The car Booth drives is a 1964 blue [[Volkswagen Karmann Ghia]] convertible. It is the same year, color, make and model of the car that [[The Bride (Kill Bill)|Beatrix "the Bride" Kiddo]] ([[Uma Thurman]]) drives in ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 2]]''.<ref name=geek-easter-eggs>{{cite news |last=Crow |first=David |url=https://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/282478/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-easter-eggs-references |title=Once Upon a Time in Hollywood Easter Eggs Guide |website=[[Den of Geek]] |access-date=August 31, 2019 |date=August 17, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190831010250/https://www.denofgeek.com/us/movies/282478/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-easter-eggs-references |archive-date=August 31, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> Similarly, Rick Dalton's 1966 [[Cadillac de Ville series|Cadillac de Ville]] is the same as the car driven by Mr. Blonde ([[Michael Madsen]]) in ''[[Reservoir Dogs]]''. It is owned by Madsen.<ref name=vintage-cars/>
Tarantino-invented fast food chain [[Big Kahuna Burger]] appears on a billboard. The final scene features Rick Dalton in a commercial for fictional Red Apple cigarettes, which appear in many Tarantino films.<ref name=gamespot-easter-eggs/><ref name=easter-eggs/><ref name="Archive footage"/><ref name=geek-easter-eggs/>
== Historical accuracy == In a scene, Sharon Tate goes into Larry Edmunds Bookshop and purchases a copy of ''[[Tess of the d'Urbervilles]]''. In real life, Tate gave a copy to Roman Polanski shortly before her death. Years later, Polanski directed the film adaptation, ''[[Tess (1979 film)|Tess]]'', dedicating it to Tate. Dalton mentions he owns his house on advice from "[[Edmond O'Brien|Eddie O'Brien]]." Tate and Polanski's [[Yorkie Terrier]] in the film is named "Dr. Sapirstein," as was Tate's Yorkie in real life, named after the doctor portrayed by [[Ralph Bellamy]] in ''Rosemary's Baby''. The carrier she puts the dog in is the same one the real Tate actually owned. The outfit Margot Robbie wears in the Bruin Theater scene is the same one Tate wore in ''[[Eye of the Devil]]''.<ref name=geek-easter-eggs/>
[[File:Fox Bruin Theater (Westwood).jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|The [[Fox Bruin Theater]]]]
In the film, Tate goes to see ''[[The Wrecking Crew (1968 film)|The Wrecking Crew]]'' at the [[Bruin Theater]]. She convinces the theater's employees that she stars in the movie after they fail to recognize her. Tarantino stated the idea came to him from an experience he had. When ''[[True Romance]]'' was released, he saw it at the same theater, where he eventually convinced its employees that he wrote the script.<ref name=cinema-blend>{{cite news |last=O'Connell |first=Sean |url=https://www.cinemablend.com/podcast/2476541/will-quentin-tarantinos-last-movie-be-star-trek-the-director-talks-about-a-loophole |title=Will Quentin Tarantino's Last Movie Be Star Trek? The Director Talks About A 'Loophole' |website=CinemaBlend |access-date=August 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190814190145/https://www.cinemablend.com/podcast/2476541/will-quentin-tarantinos-last-movie-be-star-trek-the-director-talks-about-a-loophole |archive-date=August 14, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
On the set of ''[[Batman (TV show)|Batman]]'', for a crossover episode with ''[[The Green Hornet (TV series)|The Green Hornet]]'', a fight was scripted with Kato (Bruce Lee) losing to [[Robin (character)|Robin]] ([[Burt Ward]]). When Lee received the script, he refused to do it, so it was changed to a draw. When the cameras rolled, Lee stalked Ward until Ward backed away. Lee laughed and told him he was "lucky it is a TV show."<ref name=Kato-show>{{cite news |url=https://www.newsweek.com/bruce-lee-king-fu-martial-arts-390811 |title=The Kato Show: Bruce Lee as the Green Hornet's Sidekick |website=[[Newsweek]] |access-date=August 26, 2019 |date=November 20, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190831111350/https://www.newsweek.com/bruce-lee-king-fu-martial-arts-390811 |archive-date=August 31, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> In the film, Cliff Booth reminisces about fighting Lee on the set of ''The Green Hornet''; the fight is interrupted before its conclusion, after each fighter has won one round each. Booth refers to Lee as "Kato."<ref name=controversial-scene/>
According to Rudolph Altobelli, who rented the house to Polanski and Tate, in March 1969, Charles Manson showed up looking for [[Terry Melcher]]. Polanski's friend Shahrokh Hatami also said he saw Manson enter the grounds. Hatami approached Manson, asking him what he wanted. He told Hatami he was looking for Melcher. Hatami responded the house was the Polanski residence and perhaps Melcher lived in the guest house. Altobelli told Manson that Melcher no longer lived there.<ref>{{cite news |last=Caldwell |first=Earl |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1970/10/22/archives/manson-put-at-tate-home-5-months-before-killings.html |title=Manson Put at Tate Home 5 Months Before Killings |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=August 26, 2019 |date=October 22, 1970 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190826230558/https://www.nytimes.com/1970/10/22/archives/manson-put-at-tate-home-5-months-before-killings.html |archive-date=August 26, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> This happens in the film, with Sebring in place of Altobelli and Hatami.
On the night of August 8, 1969, Patricia Krenwinkel, Charles Watson, and Susan Atkins broke into Polanski's and Tate's house, leading to the murders of Tate (eight-and-a-half months pregnant), Sebring, Wojciech Frykowski, and Abigail Folger. In the film, they go to Tate's house to commit the murders but instead end up breaking into Dalton's house after he interrupts them.<ref name=helter-skelter/> Linda Kasabian went along that night as she was the only Family member with a valid driver's license, though she did not murder anyone and stayed outside the whole time. In the film, she also goes along but does not participate.<ref name=helter-skelter/> Watson told his victims, "I'm the Devil, and I came to do the Devil's business." In the film, he says it to Cliff Booth.<ref name=devils-business>{{cite news |last=Romano |first=Evan |url=https://www.menshealth.com/entertainment/a28521042/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-devil-line-real-tex-watson/ |title=Was that Creepy Line from Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood Real? |website=[[Men's Health]] |access-date=August 20, 2019 |date=July 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190820181956/https://www.menshealth.com/entertainment/a28521042/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-devil-line-real-tex-watson/ |archive-date=August 20, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> In the film, Atkins convinces the others to seek revenge by killing Rick Dalton, star of a TV western. Since TV taught them to kill, it is fitting they kill the guy from TV, and "My idea is to kill the people who taught us to kill!"<ref name=how-true-to-life>{{cite news |last=Rao |first=Sonia |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2019/07/29/how-true-life-is-once-upon-time-hollywood-ending/ |title=How true to life is the 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' ending? |website=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=August 22, 2019 |date=July 29, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190803170857/https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2019/07/29/how-true-life-is-once-upon-time-hollywood-ending/ |archive-date=August 3, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=twist-ending>{{cite news |last=Wilkinson |first=Alissa |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2019/7/25/8906839/tarantino-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-spoilers-ending-manson |title=The twist ending of Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood, explained |website=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |access-date=August 22, 2019 |date=July 25, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200528145450/https://www.vox.com/culture/2019/7/25/8906839/tarantino-once-upon-time-in-hollywood-spoilers-ending-manson |archive-date=May 28, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> In real life, Manson Family member [[Nancy Pitman]] said: "We are what you have made us. We were brought up on your TV. We were brought up watching ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' and ''[[Have Gun – Will Travel]]''."<ref name=five-things>{{cite news |url=https://www.geeklygood.com/blogs/news/five-things-you-didnt-know-about-tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood |title=Five Things You Didn't Know About Tarantino's Once Upon a Time in Hollywood |website=geeklygoods |access-date=August 22, 2019 |date=July 29, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190823045625/https://geeklygood.com/blogs/news/five-things-you-didnt-know-about-tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood |archive-date=August 23, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> [[Sandra Good]] said: "You want to talk about devils and demonic and immorals and evil, go to Hollywood. We don't touch the evil of that world. We don't even skim it."<ref>{{cite news |last=Kilkenny |first=Katie |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/manson-women-followers-recall-leaders-manipulation-1230616 |title=Former Manson Followers Debate Family's Culpability: 'How Can You Point the Finger at Us?' |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |access-date=August 28, 2019 |date=August 10, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190813210823/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/manson-women-followers-recall-leaders-manipulation-1230616 |archive-date=August 13, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
The next night, the same four, along with Leslie Van Houten, Manson, and Steve Grogan, drove to Leno and Rosemary LaBianca's house, murdering the couple. Afterwards, Manson directed Kasabian to drive to an apartment complex to commit more murders. Once there, Manson left in the car alone, leaving the others to hitchhike back to Spahn Ranch. In the film, it is Kasabian who drives off, deserting others. Watson says they can hitchhike back.<ref name=helter-skelter/> Grogan was convicted of the murder of stuntman [[Donald Shea|Donald "Shorty" Shea]] on Spahn Ranch, whom he repeatedly beat with a lead pipe. === The Manson Family in Hollywood === Charles Manson once approached [[Steve McQueen]] with a script he wrote, to get him to produce it. When McQueen turned him down, an altercation happened, in which McQueen broke Manson's nose.<ref name=mcqueen-manson>{{cite news |url=https://www.esquire.com/uk/culture/film/news/a13833/steve-mcqueen-infidelity-charles-manson-murder/ |title=Steve McQueen's Womanizing Ways Stopped Him From Being Murdered By Charles Manson |website=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |access-date=August 18, 2019 |date=March 21, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208003429/http://www.esquire.com/uk/culture/film/news/a13833/steve-mcqueen-infidelity-charles-manson-murder/ |archive-date=February 8, 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> On the night of the Tate murders, Jay Sebring invited McQueen over to Tate's house; however, his date wanted to stay in.<ref>{{cite book |last=Eliot |first=Marc |title=Steve McQueen: A Biography |publisher=[[Crown Publishing Group]] |year=2011 |isbn=978-0-307-45323-5}}</ref> After the murders, it was reported that police found a Manson Family hit list with McQueen's name.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dunne|first=Dominick|title=The Way We Lived Then: Recollections of a Well Known Name Dropper|year=1999|location=New York City|publisher=[[Crown Publishing Group]]|ISBN=0-609-60388-4|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/waywelivedthenr00dunn}}</ref>
Bobby Beausoleil was an actor and [[porn star]]. He appeared in the documentary film ''[[Mondo Hollywood]]'', also featuring Sebring. [[Catherine Share]] met Beausoleil on the set of the [[softcore porn]] film ''Ramrodder''. Beausoleil introduced Share to Manson.<ref>{{cite book |title=Sinister Forces – The Manson Secret: A Grimoire of American Political Witchcraft |first=Peter |last=Lavenda |publisher=Trine Day |date=June 1, 2011 |isbn=978-0-9841858-3-2}}</ref> Atkins met Manson in San Francisco, where she had worked as an actress, portraying a [[vampire]] on [[Anton LaVey]]'s Witches Sabbath Club Show.<ref name=Guinn>{{cite book |last=Guinn |first=Jeff |title=Manson: The Life and Times of Charles Manson |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |year=2013 |isbn=978-1-4516-4518-7}}</ref> LaVey appeared with Beausoleil in ''[[Lucifer Rising (film)|Lucifer Rising]]'',<ref name=Landis>{{cite book |last=Landis |first=Bill |title=Anger: An Unauthorized Biography of Kenneth Anger |publisher=[[Harper Collins]] |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-06-016700-4}}</ref> and claimed to have been a consultant on and appeared as the Devil in Polanski's ''Rosemary's Baby''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://variety.com/1997/scene/people-news/anton-szandor-lavey-1116674361/ |title=Anton Szandor LaVey |website=Variety |access-date=August 28, 2019 |date=November 19, 1997 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190828233810/https://variety.com/1997/scene/people-news/anton-szandor-lavey-1116674361/ |archive-date=August 28, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Moffitt |first=Mike |url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/When-the-Devil-lived-in-the-Richmond-7382271.php |title=When the Devil lived in the Richmond |website=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |access-date=August 28, 2019 |date=May 4, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190829002747/https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/When-the-Devil-lived-in-the-Richmond-7382271.php |archive-date=August 29, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
== Portrayals of real-life figures== === Bruce Lee === [[File:Bruce Lee 1973.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Bruce Lee]], portrayed in the film by [[Mike Moh]]. The appearance of Lee in the film was criticized by Asian-Americans and former friends and family of him, who considered it offensive and inaccurate.]]Although its context is a daydream of Cliff Booth's rather than a "real" event in the narrative, the depiction of [[Bruce Lee]] drew criticism. Fans and contemporaries of Lee criticized his imprecise portrayal.<ref name=daughter-saddened>{{Cite web |last=Molloy |first=Tim |url=https://www.thewrap.com/bruce-lee-daughter-mockery-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-shannon-lee/ |title=Bruce Lee's Daughter Saddened by 'Mockery' in Once Upon a Time...in Hollywood |work=[[TheWrap]]|accessdate=August 17, 2019 |date=July 29, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190816174854/https://www.thewrap.com/bruce-lee-daughter-mockery-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-shannon-lee/ |archive-date=August 16, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref name=inosanto/> Lee's daughter, [[Shannon Lee|Shannon]], stated: "[Lee] was continuously marginalized and treated like kind of a nuisance of a human being by white Hollywood, which is how he's treated in the film by [Tarantino]."<ref name=inosanto>{{cite magazine |last=Yap |first=Audrey Cleo |url=https://variety.com/2019/film/features/bruce-lee-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-dan-inosanto-1203287237/ |title=Bruce Lee's Protege Recalls His Humility Amid 'Once Upon a Time' Criticism |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=August 17, 2019 |date=July 31, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190816130517/https://variety.com/2019/film/features/bruce-lee-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-dan-inosanto-1203287237/ |archive-date=August 16, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]], with whom Lee trained and appeared in ''[[Game of Death]]'', stated: "Of course, Tarantino has the artistic right to portray Bruce any way he wants. But to do so in such a sloppy and somewhat racist way is a failure both as an artist and as a human being."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Abdul-Jabbar |first=Kareem |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kareem-abdul-jabbar-bruce-lee-was-my-friend-tarantinos-movie-disrespects-him-1232544 |title=Kareem Abdul-Jabbar:Bruce Lee Was My Friend, & Tarantino's Movie Disrespects Him |accessdate=August 17, 2019 |date=August 16, 2019 |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190816194616/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kareem-abdul-jabbar-bruce-lee-was-my-friend-tarantinos-movie-disrespects-him-1232544 |archive-date=August 16, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
[[Mike Moh]], who played Lee, said he was conflicted at first: "Bruce in my mind was literally a god. ... Bruce didn't always have the most affection for stuntmen; he didn't respect all of them."<ref name=Bruce-Lee-actor>{{cite news |last=Galbraith |first=Alex |url=https://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2019/08/bruce-lee-actor-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-fight-scene |title=Bruce Lee Actor Defends 'Once Upon A Time In Hollywood' Fight Scene |website=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]] |accessdate=August 17, 2019 |date=August 4, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190817182856/https://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2019/08/bruce-lee-actor-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-fight-scene |archive-date=August 17, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> He stated, "Tarantino loves Bruce Lee; he reveres him."<ref name="Mike-Moh-Bruce-Lee">{{cite news |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-bruce-lee-mike-moh-1202163256/ |title='Once Upon a Time in Hollywood': Bruce Lee Actor Explains Why the Martial Arts King Loses to Brad Pitt |last=Lattanzio |first=Ryan |date=August 4, 2019 |access-date=August 17, 2019 |website=[[IndieWire]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190808113755/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-bruce-lee-mike-moh-1202163256/ |archive-date=August 8, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> Brad Pitt objected to an extended version of the fight, stating, "It's Bruce Lee, man!" according to stunt coordinator Robert Alonzo.<ref name="jacobshuffington">{{cite news |last1=Jacobs |first1=Matthew |title=Tarantino's Secrets, Brad's Pitt And Leo's Flames: Tales From 'Once Upon A Time In Hollywood' |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-tarantino-behind-the-scenes_n_5d434018e4b0acb57fc97dfa?guccounter=1 |accessdate=March 3, 2020 |work=Huffington Post |date=August 6, 2019}}</ref><ref name="sharfindiewire">{{cite news |last1=Sharf |first1=Zack |title=Brad Pitt Objected to Extended Bruce Lee Fight Scene in ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood’ Script |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/brad-pitt-rejected-extended-bruce-lee-fight-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-1202163376/ |accessdate=March 3, 2020 |work=IndieWire |date=August 5, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200129055246/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/brad-pitt-rejected-extended-bruce-lee-fight-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-1202163376/ |archive-date=January 29, 2020 |url-status=live }}</ref> According to Lee's friend and ''[[The Green Hornet (TV series)|The Green Hornet]]'' stuntman [[Gene LeBell]], Lee had a reputation for "kicking the shit out of the stuntmen. They couldn't convince him that he could go easy and it would still look great on film."<ref name="Debunking Mockery"/> Lee biographer Matthew Polly stated, "Bruce was very famous for being very considerate of the people below him on film sets, particularly the stuntmen. ... So in this scene, Bruce Lee is essentially calling out a stuntman and getting him fired because he's the big star.", ironically.<ref name="controversial-scene">{{cite news |last=Bruney |first=Gabrielle |url=https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/a28607548/mike-moh-bruce-lee-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-controversy |title=Why the Bruce Lee Fight in Once Upon a Time in Hollywood Has Become the Movie's Most Controversial Scene |website=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |accessdate=August 18, 2019 |date=August 7, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190807002649/https://www.esquire.com/entertainment/a28607548/mike-moh-bruce-lee-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-controversy/ |archive-date=August 7, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
Tarantino responded, saying Lee was "kind of an arrogant guy," and that Lee's widow [[Linda Lee Cadwell|Linda]] wrote in ''[[Bruce Lee: The Man Only I Knew]]'' that he could beat [[Muhammad Ali]].<ref name=inosanto/> However, the book in question has a quote from a film critic stating so, not Linda.<ref name="fuster2019">{{cite news |last1=Fuster |first1=Jeremy |title=Quentin Tarantino Defends ‘Hollywood’ Depiction of Bruce Lee: ‘He Was Kind of an Arrogant Guy’ |url=https://www.thewrap.com/tarantino-defends-bruce-lee-portrayal/ |accessdate=March 8, 2020 |work=The Wrap |date=August 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191225234420/https://www.thewrap.com/tarantino-defends-bruce-lee-portrayal/ |archive-date=December 25, 2019 |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1972, Lee himself stated: "Everybody says I must fight Ali some day. ... Look at my hand. That's a little Chinese hand. He'd kill me."<ref>{{cite book |last=Clouse |first=Robert |date=1988 |title=Bruce Lee: The Biography |publisher=Unique Publications |page=112 |isbn=978-0-86568-133-0}}</ref>
=== Sharon Tate === Tarantino gave an early script to a representative of [[Roman Polanski]], Tate's husband, to assure him that "he didn't have anything to worry about". Tarantino stated: "When it comes to Polanski, we're talking about a tragedy that would be unfathomable for most human beings."<ref name=Polanski-contacted>{{cite news |last=Sharf |first=Zack |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/roman-polanski-tarantino-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-talks-1202159276/ |title=Roman Polanski Contacted Tarantino With Questions About 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood' |website=[[Indiewire]] |accessdate=August 17, 2019 |date=July 19, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720130648/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/07/roman-polanski-tarantino-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-talks-1202159276/ |archive-date=July 20, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
Debra Tate, Sharon's sister, initially opposed the film, saying it was exploitative and perpetuated mistruths: "To celebrate the killers and the darkest portion of society as being sexy or acceptable in any way, shape or form is just perpetuating the worst of our society."<ref name="debra-tate"/> After Tarantino contacted her and showed her the script, she withdrew opposition, saying: "This movie is not what people would expect it to be when you combine the Tarantino and Manson names." She felt that Tarantino was a "very stand-up guy"; after visiting the set, she was especially impressed with Robbie, and lent her some of Sharon's jewelry and perfume to wear in the film.<ref name="debra-tate">{{cite news |url=https://www.bustle.com/p/what-does-sharon-tates-family-think-of-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-her-sister-has-spoken-out-18226104 |title=What Does Sharon Tate's Family Think Of 'Once Upon a Time in Hollywood'? Her Sister Had Spoken Out |last=Brayson |first=Johnny |accessdate=August 20, 2019 |website=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190820153629/https://www.bustle.com/p/what-does-sharon-tates-family-think-of-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-her-sister-has-spoken-out-18226104 |archive-date=August 20, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
After the premiere, a journalist mentioned to Tarantino that Robbie had few lines. Tarantino responded: "I reject your hypothesis." Robbie elaborated, "I think the moments on screen show those wonderful sides of [Tate] could be adequately done without speaking."<ref>{{cite news |title=Quentin Tarantino Passes on Question About Screen Treatment of Margot Robbie |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/05/22/movies/quentin-tarantino-margot-robbie.html?smtyp=cur&smid=tw-nytimes |date=May 22, 2019 |first=Farah |last=Nayeri |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=August 22, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2019/may/22/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-tarantino-lashes-out-at-criticism-over-female-actors |title='I reject your hypothesis': Tarantino lashes out at criticism over female actors |last=Mumford |first=Gwilym |date=May 22, 2019 |work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=August 21, 2019 |issn=0261-3077 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190821233029/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2019/may/22/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-tarantino-lashes-out-at-criticism-over-female-actors |archive-date=August 21, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> Tarantino stated: "I thought it would both be touching and pleasurable and also sad and melancholy to just spend a little time with [Tate], just existing... I wanted you to see Sharon a lot."<ref name=Tarantino-Deadline-Interview/>
=== The Manson Family === Charles Manson was convicted of the murders of Tate and four others, despite not being present, due mostly to a theory stating he was trying to instigate an [[apocalypticism|apocalyptic]] race war, in the end leaving only black Muslims and the Manson Family. The black Muslims would eventually look to Manson to lead them. According to some, Manson referred to the race war as [[Helter Skelter (scenario)|Helter Skelter]], getting the name from the [[Helter Skelter (song)|song of the same name]].<ref name=helter-skelter/><ref name=watkins>{{cite book |last=Watkins |first=Paul and Guillermo Soledad |title=My Life With Charles Manson|publisher=Bantam |year=1979 |isbn=978-0-553-12788-1}}</ref> Musician and filmmaker [[Boots Riley]] criticized the film for not portraying Helter Skelter or depicting the Family as [[white supremacy|white supremacists]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Sharf |first=Zack |url=https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/boots-riley-calls-out-tarantino-manson-family-white-supremacists-1202168736/ |title=Boots Riley Calls Out Tarantino's Hollywood for Not Depicting Manson Family as White Supremacists |website=[[IndieWire]] |access-date=August 30, 2019 |date=August 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190829013429/https://www.indiewire.com/2019/08/boots-riley-calls-out-tarantino-manson-family-white-supremacists-1202168736/ |archive-date=August 29, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>
However, according to members of the Family, the murders were not committed to start Helter Skelter but as copycat murders of [[Gary Hinman]], to convince police his killer was still at large. Bobby Beausoleil was in jail, charged with the murder. The Family was attempting to get him released.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bardach |first=Ann Louise |url=http://www.bardachreports.com/articles/oa_19811100.htm |title=Jailhouse Interview: Bobby Beausoleil |access-date=August 26, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181119004534/http://www.bardachreports.com/articles/oa_19811100.htm |archive-date=November 19, 2018 |url-status=live}}</ref> According to Jay Sebring's protege and business partner [[Jim Markham]], the murders were about a drug deal gone bad, not a race war. He believes Manson was at Tate's house the day before the murders to sell drugs to Sebring and Voytek Frykowski, which resulted in the two beating Manson up.<ref>{{cite news |last=Siegel |first=Tatiana |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/manson-family-murder-victims-friend-posits-alternative-motive-1227729 |title=Manson Victim's Friend Posits Alternative Motive: 'I Never Bought Into the Race War Theory' |website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|access-date=August 29, 2019 |date=July 30, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190731034053/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/manson-family-murder-victims-friend-posits-alternative-motive-1227729 |archive-date=July 31, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref> In his interview with [[Truman Capote]], Beausoleil said, "They burned people on dope deals. Sharon Tate and that gang."<ref>{{cite book |last=Capote |first=Truman |title=A Capote Reader |publisher=[[Random House]]|year=1987 |isbn=978-0-394-55647-5 |url-access=registration |url=https://archive.org/details/capotereader00trum }}</ref>
